snippet.textDisplay:
My honest thoughts on Felicia Sonmez of WP & Sarah Spain of ESPN: While "The right time" to bring up kobe's "mistakes" seem to always cause debate... In my opinion THERE IS NO DEBATE WHAT SO EVER that this was the absolute WRONG TIME! The time WAS THERE to do this before now including THE DAY HE PLAYED HIS FINAL GAME!!!!
NOT WHILE THE HELICOPTER HE PERISHED ON IS STILL BURNING!!! & NOT BEFORE HE IS LAID TO REST & WHEN HES NOW UNABLE TO DEFEND HIMSELF EVER AGAIN!!!

If there was undeniable proof of such actions or if Kobe was found guilty.. I would not make the above statements. BUT Kobe was not found guilty because IT WAS THROWN OUT IN COURT! the accuser did not want to proceed! Remember Kobe is Black so if the white woman did proceed she could have had him put away for good & ended his career even if she was lying! A SETTLEMENT IS NOT AN ADMISSION OF GUILT! As much as Kobe could be Guilty, Is as much The Woman Could have been Lying all along!!!

SO THAT SAID... I am NOT saying Kobe did or didn't rape the woman I am saying given the FACTS of the court proceedings... ONLY Kobe & The Woman knows what truly happened & at this point LET GOD BE THE JUDGE, JURY & EXECUTIONER! THE END! Not only has Kobe not repeated anything anywhere near those mistakes, he has been one of the better contributing members to society & Example Setter to the highest level! Kobe represented 3 things Black Men desperately lack in life: REDEMPTION, FAMILY & FATHERHOOD!!!! NO matter what anyone says at this point, you CAN NEVER take his legacy away from me & majority of those who look like me!

snippet.textDisplay:
That reporter had what was coming to her, honestly. I get that victims need a voice and all, but she could have some damn decency and respect for the dead (not to mention, a brain). He was loved, by millions of people who were, no doubt, looking at the news of his passing, and in that time frame where his fans are down, you're going to strike? How can she not realize how stupid of a decision that was? Do you get up at a funeral for your dead grandparents and go: "Yeah, remember when she shoplifted a bunch and went to jail?" (or something similar?) What about him being famous makes it all of a sudden okay to paint in a bad light on the day of his death? You really think her friends, family, and fans want to hear and see that on twitters kobe trending section? Could she really not think for two seconds before she went all "Oopsie, I'm getting doxxed, whoa, why is this happening to me?" Really small brain play there. For however many million people there are that know him, maybe divide that by a million and a half and say that's the "grieving period" where drudging up someones past is probably not a good idea (for your own darn safety, because humans can be insane).
Sure, the article was written a long time ago, but even so, what would 4 or 5 months done to the relevance of that piece? Not much, but with the bonus of not getting death threats! Yay! Those old voices had the chance to speak out and got their retribution at the time of its writing. It's not relevant anymore other than Kobe exists in it. I think, if she wanted to release the article, she could have re-written it (to some extent, I know she's not the original author). I think a great and powerful perspective could have been "consent is extremely important, but celebrities need to remember that their fame can affect those around them" Or something like that. Or if a similar consent type case happens with another celebrity, have this old article drafted up, and go "See, this is a problem in the celebrity community and it needs to be addressed."
There was no tact in what she did, no thinking beyond her own lens. And in the state of today's "fake news" and clickbait garbage, with journalism becoming an ever more poisonous source of the content and opinions, I say she got what she deserved. Think before ya post people: that's all I'm saying. For the two people that read this: Thanks for reading

snippet.textDisplay: Sonmez was wrong here, the Post was fine in doing what it did. The story Sonmez posted was not the problem, the timing and the intent was. Had Kobe not died she wouldn't have posted that article, so the ONLY reason to do it now is to capitalize on the attention surrounding his death to effectively tell the world "Remember, he's a shit head rapist". Opinions on Kobe and that story aside right now his family is grieving his loss and the loss of one of his daughters, their daughter/sister. Attacks like this only cause more pain to them and serve no purpose, there is no net benefit to posting this story right now. TL;DR, Sonmez did it now to cause maximum hurt because she is a garbage person. That's good enough reason to suspend her if not dismiss her outright. The Post talk about fairness but posting this story now was not fair to Kobe's family. The complete lack of basic human decency is disheartening.

snippet.textDisplay:
Honest question - how long are we suppose to "punish" people? I understand that it is apart of the fabric of his story, his legacy, however, there was a documentary on HBO where he went into detail about that time. He talked about how he felt guilty and how much stress he put on Vanessa, that Vanessa even had a miscarriage because of it. He said in the documentary that he turned his life around after that. I watched it mainly because of my Mom who is the ultimate Kobe fan.

I am not a Kobe fan like that, while admittedly I did cry when I found out the news. The whole situation is devastating and heart breaking.

But my main question is how long are we as a society suppose to punish people? We don't have all the facts - no? We don't know what happened that night - no? And we don't know what was said in the civil case? He apologized to his woman, to the public, and his family about it. And that's more than we got from a R. Kelly, a Harvey Weinstein, a Bill Cosby. No one's legacy is going to be perfect - and I understand there is dirt under everyone's finger nails as the build their own empire. But how long do we punish people? This case happened in 2003. I'm asking because I saw the same outrage when Aziz did his comedy special.

I'm asking seriously and would appreciate civility, which seems like a contradiction given this is a YouTube comment section.

snippet.textDisplay: I think the idea of the shooter believing he’d be freed from prison by his white supremacists buddies is a terrible argument for mental illness. If we were to frame the same situation with gangs or a mafia, in a member believing their group would free them so the sentencing didn’t matter, no one would call that mental illness. It’s just a bad prediction made by someone entrenched in bad ideologies. To put that “delusion” on par with schizophrenia is a bastardization of true schizophrenia. Granted the guy might have mental illness, and even may have schizophrenia, giving that as an example of his delusions or symptoms is weak at best and damaging to the protection of individuals with mental illness at worst.

snippet.textDisplay: Felicia Sommez's post was unprofessional as a journalist because it lacked empathy for those who are grieving Kobe Bryant's Death. He, like everyone, has made bad decisions in his life, but the extent of his positive impact is far more impressive and broad than those few situations that people demonize him for. I personally felt deeply upset at his passing because of how much he inspired me to become a better person in life and in my craft, and as such believe that to post such a negative article on his life so shortly after his death for a reporter is gross and selfish. People need time to think about what his legacy meant to them and what his position as a role model had on their lives before being reminded of his low points and mistakes, and only a few days does not do justice to how many people had loved/been motivated by Kobe Bryant

snippet.textDisplay: I agree that i wish the blackmailer got what they deserved, but Nikkie knows as a public figure releasing the name could ruin their life in the same way her blackmailer was trying to ruin hers, and she probably has enough sympathy to know she doesn’t want that for anyone. I thought the video did a good job of addressing not only this but about the privilege Nikkie has to do this as a public figure, and encourages trans folk who aren’t in her position of power to take the proper step for their protection, as well as addresses her privileges of having a supportive family and being able to transition early, allowing for her to “pass” very easily. I think it was a very well thought out video that addressed everything that needed to be addressed, and Nikkie handled the situation with an amazing amount of grace most people on the internet probably wouldn’t have if they were in her shoes.

snippet.textDisplay:
I fully support the right of reporters to write about relevant and pertinent information, as they wish. As long as it’s factual.

That being said, there is a time and place for certain discussions. First of all, because there are real people mourning real losses, and if your goal is to make your point heard and understood... well, emotionally charged situations are certainly not the best time to accomplish that. Second, making controversial implications/accusations/etc at the wrong time may evoke reactions that are consequential to ones career. That said, it is also the right of the public to react as they see fit to the information put in front of them.

snippet.textDisplay: As far as the Washington Post tweet, it's timing is in poor taste.  I mean this could have been tweeted after they buried the man first.   It's certainly a fair topic, but maybe not why the wreck is still burning.  This Kobe case really showed how flawed news reporting is in this country.  Secondly, why does her being a sexual assault victim have any bearing on the case?   It's as if she used it as a way to stem criticism.  Because if she tweeted because she had a personal reaction she should have wrote an article about it.  She just retweeted someone else's work.  It would have been more impactful had she shared how her experience has affected her.
